docs.title: App Docs
docs.text: Some docs about applications.

docs.title: 1. What Is Homebrew?
docs.text:
Homebrew is a package manager for macOS (and Linux).

In simple terms:

Homebrew lets you install, update, and manage software from the terminal with one command.

Instead of:

  • downloading .dmg files
  • clicking through installers
  • manually managing versions

You can just run:

brew install git

and you’re done.

As an app founder, Homebrew is essential because it:

  • makes developer machines reproducible
  • speeds up onboarding
  • avoids dependency chaos
  • works perfectly with CI / automation

docs.title: 2. What Problems Does Homebrew Solve?
docs.text:
Before Homebrew, macOS users had these issues:

Problem Example Manual installs Downloading MySQL, Python, Node separately Version conflicts App A needs Python 3.9, App B needs 3.11 No easy updates Reinstall everything manually Hard to automate New team member setup takes hours

Homebrew solves all of them via CLI-based package management.

docs.title: 3. How Homebrew Works (Conceptually)
docs.text: Homebrew is built on a few core ideas:

docs.title: 3.1 Formulae and Casks
docs.text:
• Formula → command-line tools Example: git, python, mysql
  • Cask → GUI apps Example: google-chrome, visual-studio-code, docker

Think of it as:

brew install → CLI tools
brew install --cask → GUI apps

docs.title: 3.2 Where Homebrew Installs Software
docs.text:
On Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3):

/opt/homebrew

On Intel Macs:

/usr/local

Homebrew:

  • keeps everything isolated
  • does NOT mess with system files
  • avoids breaking macOS

This is one reason Apple developers trust it.

docs.title: 4.1 System Requirements
docs.text:
• macOS
  • Command Line Tools (Xcode tools)

If you don’t have them, Homebrew will install them automatically.

docs.title: 4.2 Install Command (Official)
docs.text:
Run this in Terminal:

/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

What this script does:

  1. Checks your system
  2. Installs Homebrew files
  3. Configures shell environment
  4. Verifies installation

docs.title: 4.3 Verify Installation
docs.text:
brew --version

If you see a version number, you’re good.

docs.title: 5.1 Search for Software
docs.text: brew search python

docs.title: 5.2 Install a Package
docs.text:
brew install python

Homebrew automatically:

  • resolves dependencies
  • downloads source/binaries
  • installs correctly
  • links executables

docs.title: 5.3 Install GUI Apps (Cask)
docs.text:
brew install --cask visual-studio-code

Other common examples:

brew install --cask google-chrome
brew install --cask docker
brew install --cask iterm2

docs.title: 5.4 List Installed Packages
docs.text:
brew list

For GUI apps:

brew list --cask

docs.title: 5.5 Update Homebrew Itself
docs.text:
brew update

This updates:

  • package definitions
  • available versions

docs.title: 5.6 Upgrade Installed Software
docs.text:
brew upgrade

Upgrade a specific package:

brew upgrade python

docs.title: 5.7 Uninstall Software
docs.text:
brew uninstall python
brew uninstall --cask google-chrome

Clean leftover files:

brew cleanup

docs.title: 6. Common Beginner Mistakes (And How to Avoid Them)
❌ Using sudo with brew
docs.text:
sudo brew install xxx   # WRONG

✅ Correct:

brew install xxx

Homebrew manages permissions itself.

docs.title: ❌ Mixing system Python with Homebrew Python
docs.text:
macOS comes with a system Python. Always prefer Homebrew’s version:

which python3

Expected:

/opt/homebrew/bin/python3

docs.title: ❌ Forgetting to update
docs.text:
Best practice:

brew update && brew upgrade

Run weekly.

docs.title: 7.1 Typical Developer Setup
docs.text:
brew install git
brew install python
brew install node
brew install mysql
brew install redis
brew install --cask docker
brew install --cask visual-studio-code

This setup takes minutes, not hours.

docs.title: 7.2 Onboarding New Team Members
docs.text:
Many startups keep a setup script:

brew bundle

Which installs everything from a Brewfile.

Example Brewfile:

brew "git"
brew "python"
brew "node"

cask "visual-studio-code"
cask "docker"

This is a founder-level productivity trick.

docs.title: 8. Homebrew vs Other Package Managers
docs.text:
Tool Platform Notes Homebrew macOS/Linux Best for macOS apt Linux Ubuntu/Debian yum/dnf Linux RedHat/Fedora winget Windows Windows official

If you develop on macOS, Homebrew is the standard.

docs.title: 9. Is Homebrew Safe?
docs.text:
Yes.

Reasons:

  • Open source
  • Widely audited
  • Used by Apple engineers
  • Huge community support

Still, best practice:

  • Install only what you need
  • Keep Homebrew updated

docs.title: 10. Final Advice From an App Founder
docs.text:
If you’re serious about:

  • app development
  • backend engineering
  • data science
  • DevOps
  • startup productivity

👉 Learn Homebrew early.

It will:

  • save time
  • reduce bugs
  • make your environment predictable
  • scale with your career

docs.title: Homebrew-02: Services
docs.text: Advanced Homebrew: Managing Services (MySQL, Redis, PostgreSQL, …)

docs.title: 1. What Are “Services” in Homebrew?
docs.text:
In Homebrew, a service is a program that:

  • runs in the background
  • starts automatically (optionally at login / boot)
  • exposes a port or socket
  • behaves like a system daemon

Typical examples:

  • MySQL / PostgreSQL → databases
  • Redis → cache
  • Nginx → web server
  • RabbitMQ → message broker

Homebrew manages services using launchd on macOS.

docs.title: 2. The brew services Command
docs.text:
Homebrew extends basic package management with:

brew services

This integrates Homebrew packages with macOS’s launchd system.

docs.title: 2.1 Check Available Commands
docs.text:
brew services --help

Core subcommands:

  • start
  • stop
  • restart
  • list
  • run

docs.title: 3.1 Install MySQL
docs.text:
brew install mysql

Homebrew installs:

  • binaries
  • default config files
  • a launchd service definition

docs.title: 3.2 Start MySQL as a Service
docs.text:
brew services start mysql

This means:

  • MySQL runs in the background
  • It auto-starts on login
  • Managed by launchd

You should see output like:

Successfully started `mysql` (label: homebrew.mxcl.mysql)

docs.title: 3.3 Check Service Status
docs.text:
brew services list

Example output:

Name    Status  User     File
mysql   started yourname ~/Library/LaunchAgents/homebrew.mxcl.mysql.plist
redis   stopped

docs.title: 4.1 brew services start
docs.text:
brew services start mysql
  • Runs as a background daemon
  • Restarts on login
  • Best for daily development

docs.title: 4.2 brew services run
docs.text:
brew services run mysql
  • Runs in foreground
  • Stops when terminal closes
  • Useful for debugging

Founder tip: 👉 Use run when tuning configs or debugging startup failures.

docs.title: 5.1 Stop a Service
docs.text:
brew services stop mysql

This:

  • stops the daemon
  • prevents auto-start

docs.title: 5.2 Restart a Service
docs.text:
brew services restart mysql

Use this after:

  • changing config files
  • upgrading versions

docs.title: 6.1 MySQL
docs.text:
Start:

brew services start mysql

Connect:

mysql -u root

Config location (Apple Silicon):

/opt/homebrew/etc/my.cnf

Data directory:

/opt/homebrew/var/mysql

docs.title: 6.2 Redis
docs.text:
Install:

brew install redis

Start:

brew services start redis

Check:

redis-cli ping

Expected:

PONG

docs.title: 6.3 PostgreSQL
docs.text:
Install:

brew install postgresql@15

Start:

brew services start postgresql@15

Connect:

psql postgres

docs.title: 6.4 Nginx
docs.text:
Install:

brew install nginx

Start:

brew services start nginx

Default port:

http://localhost:8080

Config:

/opt/homebrew/etc/nginx/nginx.conf

docs.title: 7.1 Upgrade a Service Package
docs.text:
brew upgrade mysql

Important:

  • Homebrew does not auto-restart services
  • Restart manually
brew services restart mysql

docs.title: 7.2 Check for Breaking Changes
docs.text:
Before major upgrades:

brew info mysql

Read:

  • caveats
  • migration notes

Founder rule:

Never blindly upgrade databases on a production-like environment.

docs.title: 8.1 User-Level Services (Default)
docs.text:
Homebrew services run as:

your macOS user

This is intentional:

  • safer
  • no sudo
  • fewer permission bugs

docs.title: 8.2 System-Wide Services (Advanced)
docs.text:
You can run system-level services:

sudo brew services start mysql

This installs to:

/Library/LaunchDaemons

⚠️ Not recommended unless:

  • you know launchd well
  • you need system-wide access

docs.title: 9.1 Check Service List
docs.text:
brew services list

Look for:

  • error
  • stopped

docs.title: 9.2 Run in Foreground
docs.text:
brew services run mysql

Errors will appear directly in terminal.

docs.title: 9.3 Check Logs
docs.text:
Example (MySQL):

tail -f /opt/homebrew/var/mysql/$(hostname).err

Logs are your best friend.

docs.title: 10. Homebrew Services vs Docker
docs.text:
Homebrew Services Docker Lightweight Heavier Native performance Containerized Easy local dev Production parity Fast startup Slower startup

Founder advice:

  • Use Homebrew services for local development
  • Use Docker for production simulation

docs.title: ✅ Do
docs.text:
• Keep services minimal
  • Start only what you need
  • Restart after upgrades
  • Track configs in Git

docs.title: ❌ Don’t
docs.text:
• Run everything at login
  • Mix system and brew installs
  • Ignore logs

docs.title: 12. Real Founder Workflow Example
docs.text:
Daily routine:

brew update
brew upgrade
brew services list

Project startup:

brew services start mysql
brew services start redis

Project shutdown:

brew services stop mysql
brew services stop redis

Simple, predictable, scalable.

docs.title: 13. Final Thoughts
docs.text:
Homebrew services turn macOS into a clean, developer-grade workstation.

Once you master:

  • brew install
  • brew services
  • config locations
  • upgrade workflows

You’ll have:

  • fewer bugs
  • faster setups
  • happier teams

docs.title: 1. What is a Brewfile?
docs.text:
A Brewfile is a plain text file used by Homebrew Bundle to describe all the software you want Homebrew to install.

You can think of it as:

📦 “requirements.txt” for Homebrew

With a Brewfile, you can:

  • Reinstall your development environment on a new Mac in one command
  • Share your setup with teammates
  • Keep your tools under version control (Git)

docs.title: 2. When Should You Use a Brewfile?
docs.text:
Use a Brewfile if you:

  • Reinstall macOS or switch to a new Mac
  • Manage multiple Macs with the same environment
  • Want reproducible dev setups
  • Are tired of re-installing tools manually

docs.title: 3. Installing Homebrew Bundle
docs.text:
Homebrew Bundle comes with Homebrew by default.

Verify it’s available:

brew bundle --version

If it works, you’re ready 👍

docs.title: 4. Basic Brewfile Structure
docs.text:
A Brewfile is usually named Brewfile (no extension).

Example:

brew "git"
brew "wget"

cask "google-chrome"
cask "visual-studio-code"

tap "homebrew/cask-fonts"
cask "font-fira-code"

docs.title: Common directives
docs.text: Directive Meaning brew CLI tools cask GUI apps tap Additional repositories mas Mac App Store apps

docs.title: 5. Creating a Brewfile Automatically
docs.text:
If you already have many packages installed, let Homebrew generate one for you:

brew bundle dump

This creates a Brewfile in the current directory.

docs.title: Include everything (recommended)
docs.text:
brew bundle dump --describe --force
  • --describe → adds comments
  • --force → overwrite existing Brewfile

docs.title: 6. Installing from a Brewfile
docs.text:
To install everything listed in a Brewfile:

brew bundle

Or explicitly specify the file:

brew bundle --file Brewfile

Homebrew will:

  • Install missing packages
  • Skip already installed ones

docs.title: 7. Brewfile Example (Realistic Setup)
docs.text:
# Taps
tap "homebrew/cask"
tap "homebrew/cask-fonts"

# CLI tools
brew "git"
brew "zsh"
brew "tmux"
brew "htop"
brew "python"

# GUI applications
cask "iterm2"
cask "visual-studio-code"
cask "google-chrome"
cask "raycast"

# Fonts
cask "font-jetbrains-mono"

# Mac App Store apps
mas "Xcode", id: 497799835

docs.title: 8. Managing Mac App Store Apps (mas)
docs.text:
First install mas:

brew install mas

Find an app ID:

mas search Xcode

Example entry:

mas "Xcode", id: 497799835

docs.title: 9. Common Brew Bundle Commands
docs.text:
Command Description brew bundle Install everything brew bundle dump Generate Brewfile brew bundle check Check missing packages brew bundle cleanup Remove unlisted packages brew bundle list Show Brewfile entries

⚠️ cleanup can uninstall software — use carefully.

docs.title: ✅ Keep Brewfile in Git
docs.text:
git add Brewfile
git commit -m "Add Brewfile"

docs.title: ✅ One Brewfile per machine (optional)
docs.text:
Brewfile
Brewfile.work
Brewfile.personal

Install with:

brew bundle --file Brewfile.work

docs.title: ✅ Comment generously
docs.text: brew "ffmpeg" # video processing

docs.title: 11. Where Should I Put the Brewfile?
docs.text:
Common choices:

  • ~/Brewfile
  • ~/.config/homebrew/Brewfile
  • Inside your dotfiles repo

Then run:

brew bundle --file ~/Brewfile

docs.title: 12. Brewfile vs Manual Install
docs.text: Manual brew install Brewfile Easy for one tool Perfect for full setup Hard to reproduce Fully reproducible No history Git-friendly

docs.title: 13. Typical Workflow (Recommended)
docs.text:
# On old Mac
brew bundle dump --force
git commit -am "Update Brewfile"

# On new Mac
brew bundle

Done 🎉

docs.title: 14. Summary
docs.text:
• Brewfile = declarative package list
  • One command restores your Mac environment
  • Essential for developers and power users
  • Works great with Git and dotfiles

docs.title: 1. What is brew leaves?
docs.text:
In Homebrew terms:

  • Leaves = formulae you explicitly installed yourself
  • Non-leaves = dependencies that were installed only because something else needed them

👉 brew leaves shows the “top-level” packages you actually care about.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
If you install:

brew install git

Homebrew may also install:

  • gettext
  • pcre2
  • ca-certificates

But:

brew leaves

will show:

git

docs.title: Show all leaves
docs.text:
brew leaves

Output:

git
python
wget
node

This means:

  • You directly installed git, python, wget, node
  • Everything else is just dependencies

docs.title: ① Understand your environment
docs.text: See what you intentionally installed, not the clutter.

docs.title: ② Clean up Homebrew safely
docs.text: You can remove unused dependencies without breaking your main tools.

docs.title: ③ Rebuild a system
docs.text:
brew leaves is perfect when:

  • Migrating to a new Mac
  • Creating a Brewfile
  • Auditing installed software

docs.title: brew list
docs.text:
brew list
  • Shows everything installed
  • Includes dependencies
  • Often very long

docs.title: brew leaves
docs.text:
brew leaves
  • Shows only top-level formulae
  • Much shorter
  • Human-friendly

📌 Think of it as:

brew leaves = what *I* asked for

docs.title: 5. Show Leaves with Descriptions
docs.text:
brew leaves | xargs brew desc

Example output:

git: Distributed revision control system
python: Interpreted, interactive, object-oriented programming language
wget: Internet file retriever

Useful when you:

  • Forgot why you installed something
  • Are reviewing an old machine

docs.title: Step 1: Check for unused deps
docs.text:
brew autoremove --dry-run
  • Shows what can be removed
  • Does NOT delete anything yet

docs.title: Step 2: Actually remove them
docs.text:
brew autoremove

Safe because:

  • Homebrew will not remove leaves
  • Only removes unused dependencies

docs.title: 7. Remove a Leaf Package
docs.text:
brew uninstall wget

After removing a leaf, you can clean up:

brew autoremove

docs.title: 8. Mark / Unmark Leaves Manually
docs.text: Sometimes you want to keep a dependency permanently.

docs.title: Mark as a leaf
docs.text:
brew install foo

or if already installed:

brew link foo

docs.title: Unmark as a leaf
docs.text:
brew unlink foo

⚠️ Advanced usage, but useful for power users.

docs.title: 9. Use brew leaves to Create a Brewfile
docs.text:
A very common workflow:

brew leaves > leaves.txt

Or directly:

brew bundle dump --describe

Internally, Homebrew uses the same idea:

  • Leaves = what goes into your Brewfile

docs.title: 10. Typical Beginner Workflow
docs.text:
# See what you installed on purpose
brew leaves

# Preview cleanup
brew autoremove --dry-run

# Clean safely
brew autoremove

# List everything (if needed)
brew list

docs.title: 11. Mental Model (Important)
docs.text:
Think of Homebrew as a tree:

git
 ├─ gettext
 ├─ pcre2
 └─ ca-certificates
  • Leaves = roots you planted
  • Dependencies = branches that grew automatically

brew leaves shows the roots 🌱

docs.title: 12. Summary
docs.text: Command What it does brew leaves Show packages you explicitly installed brew list Show everything brew autoremove Remove unused dependencies brew desc Show package descriptions brew bundle dump Create Brewfile

• equation

    • center

docs.text:

    graphicx,

docs.title: 1. What Is LaTeX?
docs.text:
LaTeX is a typesetting system widely used for:

  • Academic papers 📄
  • Theses and dissertations
  • Mathematical formulas
  • Technical books and slides

Instead of formatting text by clicking buttons (like in Word), you write plain text with commands, and LaTeX handles the layout automatically.

Think of LaTeX as: “content first, formatting later.”

docs.title: 2. When Should You Use LaTeX?
docs.text:
LaTeX is especially good if you:

  • Write math-heavy documents
  • Care about professional layout
  • Need cross-references, citations, or bibliographies
  • Want documents that are easy to maintain

Not ideal if you just want quick casual notes.

docs.title: 3. How LaTeX Works (Big Picture)
docs.text:
LaTeX follows this workflow:

.tex file  →  LaTeX compiler  →  PDF

You write a .tex file, then compile it into a PDF.

Popular compilers:

  • pdflatex
  • xelatex (recommended for Unicode / Chinese)
  • lualatex

docs.title: Option 1: Online (Recommended for Beginners)
docs.text:
• Overleaf (https://www.overleaf.com)
    • No installation
    • Real-time preview
    • Great for collaboration

docs.title: Option 2: Local Installation
docs.text:
• macOS: MacTeX
  • Windows: MiKTeX
  • Linux: TeX Live

docs.title: Minimal Example
docs.text:
\documentclass{article}

\begin{document}

Hello, LaTeX!

\end{document}

Explanation:

  • \documentclass{article} → document type
  • \begin{document} → start content
  • \end{document} → end content

Compile it, and you get a PDF saying Hello, LaTeX!

docs.title: 6. Document Structure
docs.text:
A typical LaTeX file looks like this:

\documentclass{article}

% Preamble (settings)
\usepackage{amsmath}

\begin{document}

% Content
\section{Introduction}
This is the introduction.

\end{document}

docs.title: Two Main Parts
docs.text:
1. Preamble
    • Document class
    • Packages
    • Global settings
  2. Document body
    • Text
    • Sections
    • Figures, tables, formulas

docs.title: Paragraphs
docs.text:
Leave a blank line to start a new paragraph.

This is the first paragraph.

This is the second paragraph.

docs.title: Bold / Italic
docs.text:
\textbf{Bold text}
\textit{Italic text}

docs.title: Line Break
docs.text:
This is a line.\\
This is a new line.

docs.title: 8. Sections and Headings
docs.text:
\section{Section}
\subsection{Subsection}
\subsubsection{Subsubsection}

LaTeX automatically numbers them.

docs.title: Unordered List
docs.text:
\begin{itemize}
  \item Apple
  \item Banana
  \item Orange
\end{itemize}

docs.title: Ordered List
docs.text:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item First
  \item Second
  \item Third
\end{enumerate}

docs.title: Inline Math
docs.text: Einstein said $E = mc^2$.

docs.title: Display Math
docs.text:
\[
E = mc^2
\]

docs.title: Common Math Commands
docs.text:
\frac{a}{b}      % fraction
\sqrt{x}        % square root
x^2             % superscript
x_1             % subscript

Example:

\[
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n x_i
\]

docs.title: 11. Figures
docs.text:
\usepackage{graphicx}

\begin{figure}[h]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=0.6\textwidth]{example.png}
  \caption{An example image}
  \label{fig:example}
\end{figure}

You can reference it later:

Figure~\ref{fig:example}

docs.title: 12. Tables
docs.text:
\begin{tabular}{c c c}
A & B & C \\
1 & 2 & 3 \\
4 & 5 & 6
\end{tabular}

For professional tables, later learn:

  • booktabs
  • tabularx

docs.title: 13. Packages (Very Important)
docs.text:
Packages extend LaTeX’s functionality.

Common beginner packages:

\usepackage{amsmath}   % better math
\usepackage{graphicx}  % images
\usepackage{hyperref}  % links

docs.title: 14. Comments
docs.text:
Anything after % is a comment.

% This is a comment
This text will appear. % This will not

docs.title: 15. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text:
❌ Forgetting \end{document} ❌ Missing a closing brace {} ❌ Using Word-style formatting habits ❌ Forgetting to include required packages

LaTeX error messages can look scary—read the first error, not the last.

docs.title: 16. Recommended Learning Path
docs.text:
1. Basic document structure
  2. Sections and text
  3. Math formulas
  4. Figures and tables
  5. References and bibliography (biblatex)
  6. Templates (articles, thesis, Beamer slides)

docs.title: 17. Where to Go Next
docs.text:
• Overleaf tutorials
  • LaTeX Wikibook
  • Learn specific templates (paper / thesis / Beamer)

docs.title: 18. Final Advice
docs.text:
LaTeX has a learning curve, but once mastered, it saves huge amounts of time.

Write content first. Let LaTeX handle beauty.

docs.title: 1. What “References” Mean in LaTeX
docs.text:
In LaTeX, references usually include:

  1. Cross-references inside the document
    • Sections
    • Figures
    • Tables
    • Equations
  2. Bibliographic references
    • Books
    • Papers
    • Websites

LaTeX handles both automatically, ensuring:

  • Correct numbering
  • Consistent formatting
  • Easy updates

docs.title: Core Idea
docs.text:
LaTeX uses a three-step mechanism:

\label{key}
\ref{key}
\pageref{key}
  • \label{} → define a reference point
  • \ref{} → reference the number
  • \pageref{} → reference the page number

docs.title: Example: Section Reference
docs.text:
\section{Introduction}
\label{sec:intro}

As discussed in Section~\ref{sec:intro}, ...

📌 Best practice:

  • Put \label right after \section, \caption, or equation.

docs.title: Example: Figure Reference
docs.text:
\begin{figure}[h]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{example.png}
  \caption{System architecture}
  \label{fig:arch}
\end{figure}

Figure~\ref{fig:arch} shows the overall design.

docs.title: Example: Equation Reference
docs.text:
\begin{equation}
E = mc^2
\label{eq:einstein}
\end{equation}

Equation~\ref{eq:einstein} is well known.

docs.title: 3. Naming Conventions for Labels (Very Important)
docs.text:
Good label naming avoids confusion in large documents.

Common conventions:

sec:intro
fig:architecture
tab:results
eq:newton

Pattern:

type:description

This makes references readable and maintainable.

docs.title: 4. Hyperlinks with hyperref
docs.text:
To make references clickable, use:

\usepackage{hyperref}

Now:

  • Section references
  • Figure references
  • Citations

become clickable links in the PDF.

Recommended order:

\usepackage{hyperref} % load this last

docs.title: 5. Bibliography: The Big Picture
docs.text:
There are two main approaches:

Method Recommendation thebibliography Small documents BibTeX / biblatex Medium & large documents ✅

We focus on biblatex, which is modern and flexible.

docs.title: Step 1: Load the Package
docs.text:
\usepackage[
  backend=biber,
  style=authoryear
]{biblatex}

\addbibresource{references.bib}
  • backend=biber → modern backend
  • style=authoryear → author–year style

docs.title: Step 2: Create a .bib File
docs.text:
File: references.bib

@book{knuth1984texbook,
  author    = {Donald E. Knuth},
  title     = {The TeXbook},
  year      = {1984},
  publisher = {Addison-Wesley}
}

@article{lamport1994latex,
  author  = {Leslie Lamport},
  title   = {LaTeX: A Document Preparation System},
  journal = {Addison-Wesley},
  year    = {1994}
}

Each entry has a citation key:

knuth1984texbook
lamport1994latex

docs.title: Basic Citation
docs.text: \cite{knuth1984texbook}

docs.title: Author–Year Style
docs.text: \textcite{lamport1994latex}

docs.title: Multiple Citations
docs.text:
\cite{knuth1984texbook,lamport1994latex}

LaTeX handles formatting automatically.

docs.title: 8. Printing the Bibliography
docs.text:
Where you want the reference list:

\printbibliography

Usually at the end of the document.

docs.title: 9. Compilation Workflow (Very Important)
docs.text:
When using biblatex + biber:

xelatex main.tex
biber main
xelatex main.tex
xelatex main.tex

Overleaf does this automatically.

docs.title: 10. Common Citation Styles
docs.text:
Popular styles:

style=numeric
style=authoryear
style=ieee
style=apa
style=mla

Example:

\usepackage[style=ieee,backend=biber]{biblatex}

docs.title: 11. Referencing Without Showing Numbers
docs.text:
Sometimes you want text only:

\nameref{sec:intro}

This prints the section title instead of the number (requires hyperref).

docs.title: “Citation undefined”
docs.text: ✔ Run LaTeX multiple times ✔ Check citation keys ✔ Ensure .bib file is added

docs.title: References not clickable
docs.text: ✔ Load hyperref ✔ Load it last

docs.title: Wrong bibliography style
docs.text: ✔ Change style=... ✔ Recompile fully

docs.title: 13. Best Practices for Large Documents
docs.text:
• Keep all references in one .bib file
  • Use consistent label prefixes
  • Never hard-code numbers
  • Let LaTeX manage everything

docs.title: 14. Minimal Working Example
docs.text:
\documentclass{article}

\usepackage{graphicx}
\usepackage{hyperref}
\usepackage[
  backend=biber,
  style=authoryear
]{biblatex}

\addbibresource{references.bib}

\begin{document}

\section{Introduction}
\label{sec:intro}

LaTeX was introduced by \textcite{lamport1994latex}.

\printbibliography

\end{document}

docs.title: 15. Final Advice
docs.text:
If you type numbers manually, you’re doing it wrong.

Once you master LaTeX references:

  • Large documents become easy
  • Reordering sections is painless
  • Formatting stays consistent forever

docs.title: 1. The Two Common Ways to Reference in Overleaf
Method 1 (Recommended): BibTeX / .bib file
docs.text:
• Best for academic papers, theses, and long documents
  • Clean separation of content and references
  • Easy to reuse and manage

docs.title: Method 2: Manual thebibliography
docs.text:
• Simple and quick
  • Suitable for short documents or reports
  • Not scalable

docs.title: Step 1: Create a .bib File
docs.text:
In Overleaf:

  • Click “+” → New File
  • Name it references.bib

Example references.bib:

@article{knuth1984texbook,
  author  = {Donald E. Knuth},
  title   = {The TeXbook},
  year    = {1984},
  publisher = {Addison-Wesley}
}

knuth1984texbook is the citation key.

docs.title: Step 2: Cite in Your .tex File
docs.text:
This book is fundamental to \LaTeX{} \cite{knuth1984texbook}.

Common citation commands:

\cite{key}        % numeric or author-year
\citep{key}       % (author, year)  [natbib]
\citet{key}       % author (year)   [natbib]

docs.title: Step 3: Add Bibliography to the Document
docs.text:
At the end of your .tex file:

\bibliographystyle{plain}
\bibliography{references}

Compile sequence in Overleaf (automatic):

LaTeX → BibTeX → LaTeX → LaTeX

Overleaf handles this for you.

docs.title: 3. Common Bibliography Styles
docs.text:
Style Description plain Numeric, sorted by author unsrt Numeric, order of appearance alpha Author-year code apalike APA-like

Example:

\bibliographystyle{unsrt}

docs.title: 4. Method 2: Manual References (thebibliography)
docs.text:
Useful for short documents.

\begin{thebibliography}{9}

\bibitem{knuth}
Donald E. Knuth,
\textit{The TeXbook},
Addison-Wesley, 1984.

\end{thebibliography}

Cite it with:

\cite{knuth}

docs.title: 5. Referencing with biblatex (Modern Alternative)
docs.text: More flexible, but slightly advanced.

docs.title: Preamble:
docs.text:
\usepackage[backend=biber,style=authoryear]{biblatex}
\addbibresource{references.bib}

docs.title: Cite:
docs.text: \cite{knuth1984texbook}

docs.title: Print bibliography:
docs.text:
\printbibliography

Overleaf supports Biber automatically.

docs.title: 6. Where to Get BibTeX Entries
docs.text:
• Google Scholar → “Cite” → BibTeX
  • arXiv
  • IEEE Xplore / ACM DL
  • Zotero / Mendeley

docs.title: 7. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text: ❌ Forgetting to add \bibliography{} ❌ Citation key mismatch ❌ Editing .bib but not recompiling ❌ Using BibTeX syntax inside .tex

docs.title: 8. Minimal Working Example
docs.text:
\documentclass{article}

\begin{document}

This is a citation example \cite{knuth1984texbook}.

\bibliographystyle{plain}
\bibliography{references}

\end{document}

docs.title: 模板代码
docs.text:
\usepackage{xeCJK}                
\xeCJKsetup{CJKmath=true}         
\usepackage[utf8]{inputenc}

docs.title: English Comments
docs.text:
\usepackage{xeCJK}                % Enable Chinese typesetting (XeLaTeX only)
\xeCJKsetup{CJKmath=true}         % Allow Chinese in math environments
\usepackage[utf8]{inputenc}       % Set input encoding to UTF-8 (optional for XeLaTeX)

docs.title: 知识解释
docs.text: 该部分确保 LaTeX 支持中文显示，适用于 XeLaTeX 编译方式。xeCJK 是最常用的中文支持宏包，CJKmath=true 让数学公式中也能显示中文。虽然 XeLaTeX 默认支持 UTF-8 编码，出于兼容性可以加上 inputenc 宏包。

docs.title: 模板代码
docs.text:
\usepackage[a4paper, top=2cm, bottom=2cm, left=3cm, right=3cm, marginparwidth=1.75cm]{geometry}

\usepackage{indentfirst}         
\setlength{\parindent}{2em}      
\setlength{\parskip}{1em}

docs.title: English Comments
docs.text:
\usepackage[...]{geometry}         % Set paper size and page margins
\usepackage{indentfirst}           % Indent the first paragraph of each section
\setlength{\parindent}{2em}        % Paragraph indent = 2 Chinese characters
\setlength{\parskip}{1em}          % Add vertical space between paragraphs

docs.title: 知识解释
docs.text: geometry 用于定义页面大小和边距，是排版设置的核心工具。indentfirst 保证每段首行缩进（包括段落开头），配合 \parindent 设置缩进量。\parskip 控制段落之间的垂直间距。

docs.title: 模板代码
docs.text:
\usepackage{xcolor}
\usepackage{sectsty}             
\sectionfont{\color{teal}}       
\subsectionfont{\color{teal}}    
\subsubsectionfont{\color{teal}}

docs.title: English Comments
docs.text:
\usepackage{xcolor}                % Enable color support
\usepackage{sectsty}              % Customize section heading styles
\sectionfont{\color{teal}}        % Set section (level 1) title color
\subsectionfont{\color{teal}}     % Set subsection title color
\subsubsectionfont{\color{teal}}  % Set subsubsection title color

docs.title: 知识解释
docs.text: 该部分用于设置标题样式，提升文档的视觉美感。通过 xcolor 提供颜色支持，sectsty 自定义标题样式。常见颜色包括 teal、red、blue 等。

docs.title: 标题位置控制与浮动体精度控制
模板代码
docs.text:
\usepackage{titling}             
\usepackage{float}

docs.title: English Comments
docs.text:
\usepackage{titling}             % Provides fine control over document titles
\usepackage{float}               % Precise placement of floating figures/tables

docs.title: 知识解释
docs.text: titling 用于灵活调整文档标题的位置和样式，例如标题前加 logo、空白等。float 允许使用 [H] 指定图表严格出现在指定位置。

docs.title: 模板代码
docs.text:
\usepackage{amsmath, amsthm}     
\usepackage[most]{tcolorbox}     

\newtcbtheorem[number within=section]{defn}{定义}%
  {colback=cyan!10!white, colframe=cyan!60!black, fonttitle=\bfseries}{def}

docs.title: English Comments
docs.text:
\usepackage{amsmath, amsthm}      % Math formula and theorem environments
\usepackage[most]{tcolorbox}      % Colored boxes for theorems and definitions

% Define a custom theorem-like environment called "定义" with styling
\newtcbtheorem[number within=section]{defn}{定义}%
  {colback=cyan!10!white, colframe=cyan!60!black, fonttitle=\bfseries}{def}

docs.title: 知识解释
docs.text: amsmath 和 amsthm 提供数学公式和定理环境支持。tcolorbox 可创建带颜色框的定理/定义/例题等模块，newtcbtheorem 创建了一个编号的“定义”环境，样式清新、实用。

docs.title: 模板代码
docs.text: \usepackage{minted}

docs.title: English Comments
docs.text: \usepackage{minted}              % Syntax highlighting for code blocks (requires -shell-escape)

docs.title: 知识解释
docs.text:
minted 是功能强大的代码高亮工具，支持多种语言，如 Python、C、Java 等。编译时需添加 -shell-escape 参数。示例使用：

\begin{minted}{python}
def hello():
    print("Hello, world!")
\end{minted}

\usepackage[inkscapelatex=false]{svg}   
\usepackage[colorlinks=true, allcolors=magenta]{hyperref}

docs.title: English Comments
docs.text:
\usepackage{graphicx}                         % For inserting images
\usepackage[inkscapelatex=false]{svg}        % Support for SVG images
\usepackage[colorlinks=true, allcolors=magenta]{hyperref} % Enable colored hyperlinks

docs.title: 知识解释
docs.text:
• graphicx 插入图片常用宏包，使用 \includegraphics。

  • svg 支持矢量图，适合用 Inkscape 导出的图片。

  • hyperref 添加 PDF 超链接，设置 colorlinks=true 可去除边框，指定链接颜色。

docs.text:
\tcbset{
  ex/.style={
    colback=lime!5!white,       % Soft background color
    colframe=lime!60!black,     % Frame color
    fonttitle=\bfseries,        % Bold title
    title=例题,                 % Default title text
    arc=4pt,                    % Rounded corners
    boxrule=0.6pt,              % Border thickness
    left=1em, right=1em,        % Horizontal padding
    top=0.8em, bottom=0.8em,    % Vertical padding
    drop shadow                 % Soft shadow effect
  }
}

docs.title: 知识解释
docs.text: 这是 tcolorbox 定义的样式名为 ex 的新框样式，默认标题为“例题”，用于高亮显示练习题、案例分析等内容，风格清新直观。
